Award.AbstractNarration: This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Virginia Cornish at Columbia University to carry out fundamental studies on technology to discover cellulase enzymes for biofuel production. One of the major bottlenecks to cost-competitive conversion of biomass to fermentable sugars for biofuel production is the high cost of the cellulase enzymes needed for biomass degradation. The Cornish laboratory has engineered a general system for coupling the growth of yeast to enzyme activity, a system that has now been adapted to detect cellulase activity and facilitate the identification of new cellulases. This strain is now being optimized so that it can be used to identify active enzymes from very large pools of candidate cellulases and is being used to search the DNA of microorganisms for novel cellulase enzymes. The optimization of the laboratory's strains around the cellulase application will also further the technology more generally, which will ultimately allow it to be applied to the detection of other hydrolase enzymes needed for biofuel production and to other classes of enzymes. This research has the potential to identify improved cellulase enzymes that could make the conversion of biomass to biofuels and other commercial products more cost-efficient, helping to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels for energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellulase enzymes are a key target for the cost-effective conversion of cellulosic biomass to biofuels. However, a major bottleneck to engineering more efficient cellulase enzymes is the lack of high-throughput assays for the discovery of improved cellulases through biodiversity mining or directed evolution. Thus, the major objective of this proposal was to engineer chemical complementation, a previously developed enzymatic assay, as a growth selection for cellulase enzymes. The second objective was to apply the developed cellulase selection to the discovery of novel cellulase enzymes via biodiversity mining. Although we aimed to search for novel cellulases via biodiversity mining, the majority of the grant period was dedicated to truly developing a robust, high-throughput counter selection for cellulase enzymes.

The first step was simply to establish the feasibility of using chemical complementation as a robust selection for cellulase enzymes. To achieve this goal, the chemical complementation system was reengineered as a counter selection that could link cellulase bond cleavage activity to yeast cell survival in vivo. The developed cellulase counter selection was able to detect cellulase activity and select improved cellulase variants from a library generated by family DNA shuffling. However, the cellulase counter selection was not robust based on an experimental framework we developed to characterize the throughput and sensitivity of growth selections. Thus, the original cellulase counter selection was too low-throughput to search the large variant libraries required for cellulase discovery via biodiversity mining.

To improve the cellulase counter selection, a few approaches were executed. The first approach was to screen a library of novel counter selection reporter genes. To carry out this effort, a system was developed to quickly construct and screen libraries of candidate reporter genes in the analogous counter selection conditions. This approach, however, did not result in any reporter genes that provided the throughput required for cellulase engineering. Thus, the cellulase counter selection was rationally redesigned to incorporate systems that would tighten reporter gene transcription levels or reduce reporter gene protein levels. Ultimately, the most promising cellulase counter selection included the Dual Tetracycline (Tet) system. The dual Tet system is well-studied and uses both an activator and repressor to tightly regulate the conditional expression of genes. A small, focused library of Tet counter selection variants were tested for the appropriate readout in selection conditions. The isolated Tet counter selection outperformed the original counter selection, significantly. The Tet counter selection can search mock libraries with up to 106 variants, which is a 104-fold improvement over the original counter selection. The enhanced throughput of the Tet counter selection opens the door to apply chemical complementation to the discovery of novel cellulase enzymes via biodiversity mining.

This project resulted in a counter selection system that is well-suited for the discovery of novel cellulase enzymes from large variant libraries, which is extremely relevant to the cellulase engineering field. However, this counter selection system is versatile and could be adapted for the discovery of other relevant bond-cleaving enzymes in biofuel production. In addition, the methods used to characterize and screen novel reporter genes for the cellulase counter selection can be broadly used by other researchers aiming to develop growth selections with the appropriate readout for their desired application.
